comment.author: 13812504@N03
comment._content:
This is the ship that disappeared in March of 1918.  Her loss is often attributed to the Bermuda Triangle.  Naval accounts indicate she may have been overloaded with manganese; her captain had replaced her supercargo with an inexperienced crewman.
Her wreck has never been found.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thanks for describing the boat's history. We'll update the record and include the possibility that this is the 1911 Naval Review in New York City, based on information from the Naval Historical Center, www.history.navy.mil/photos/sh-usn/usnsh-c/cyclops.htm

comment.author: 22968943@N05
comment._content: Looks like a 10/somthing/11 date in reverse in the upper left corner

comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content:
I knew I remembered this ship's name, yes the Bermuda triangle is why.
*Collier: full load displacement 19,360; length 542'; beam 65'; draft 27'8"; speed 15 knots.; complement 236

she was Naval Auxilliary until  May 1, 1917. This photo appears to be dated 10/01/11 in reverse on the upper left corner.
